headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the PG&E Corporation Q1 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] .I would like to introduce your hostess, Ms. Janet Loduca, you may proceed.
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the PG&E Corporation Q1 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] .
I would like to introduce your hostess, Ms. Janet Loduca, you may proceed.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Monica. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Before you hear from Tony Earley, Chris Johns and Kent Harvey, I'll remind you that our discussion today will include forward-looking statements about our outlook for future financial r
componenttext:
Thank you, Monica. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Before you hear from Tony Earley, Chris Johns and Kent Harvey, I'll remind you that our discussion today will include forward-looking statements about our outlook for future financial results based on assumption, forecast, expectation and information currently available to management. Some of the important factors that could affect the company's actual financial results are described on the second page of today's slide deck. We also encourage you to review the Form 10-Q that will be filed with the SEC later today, and a discussion of risk factors that appear there and in the 2014 annual report.
With that, I'll turn it over to Tony.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Janet, and good morning, everyone. I'm going to start with some opening remarks. And then turn it over to Chris and Kent to provide more detail on both operational and financial issues.As you know, we received the final penalty decision on the g
componenttext:
Thanks, Janet, and good morning, everyone. I'm going to start with some opening remarks. And then turn it over to Chris and Kent to provide more detail on both operational and financial issues.
As you know, we received the final penalty decision on the gas transmission pipeline investigations earlier this month which is a significant milestone. Following the San Bruno accident, we worked hard to do the right thing for the victims, their families and the community of San Bruno. We've dedicated ourselves to becoming the safest and most reliable utility in the country.
We've been working to build a culture across the company that supports this mission. And we've completed an unprecedented level of work to improve the safety of our system, much of it funded by our shareholders.
So although the final penalty assessed by the commission is the largest in state history and certainly one of the largest in the country, we've decided not to appeal. We just don't feel that prolonging the proceeding is in anyone's interest.
As we move forward, I can assure you that the lessons from San Bruno will continue to guide us. That San Bruno accident has changed the way we look at everything from the way we plan to what work we do to the way we execute and document work in the field.
Safety starts at the top. It also requires the unequivocal commitment of every employee. My management team, our employees and the unions who represent them have all made that commitment and safety has been at the heart of our decision and actions over the last several years.
I want to acknowledged that we still have a number of proceedings outstanding. On the legal front, a trial date in the federal criminal case has been set for March 8, 2016. As you know, state federal prosecutors have been investigating potential ex parte communications with the CPUC as well.
There are also still several investigations at the commission, including a new investigation of our safety culture that President Picker announced at the last commission meeting. And in fact, we welcome a conversation about safety at PG&E. We're proud of the work we've done to date. And we know we still have a lot of work to do to reearn the trust of our customers and the commission.
Over the past several years, we've hired some of the best experts in the country to help guide our efforts. Adding to that list, this spring, we announced that we've hired Julie Kane as our new Chief Ethics and Compliance Officer reporting directly to me.
Julie has deep compliance experience, largely in the highly regulated pharmaceutical industry. And her mandate is to work with our Board of Directors and our leadership team to build a best-in-class compliance program.
As Chris will discuss, we had another solid quarter in our operations. We're in the third year of a rigorous risk assessment program that we used to develop our 5-year operational plan. And I've been really pleased to see that these plans become more robust every year.
And we continue to see strong opportunities for growth as we work to build a better California. In both gas and electric operations, we'll continue to upgrade the system with a focus on reducing risk and enhancing safety and reliability through physical improvement like replacing pipes and wires and using technology to respond to our customers changing needs.
We're also working on integrating clean energy plan which we believe will offer strong support for Governor Brown's vision of reducing carbon emission.
In the coming years, we expect to see continued investment opportunities to support the interactive Grid of Things. This will facilitate the state's increasing reliance on intermittent renewables, electric vehicles, demand-side management tools and energy storage. We have a number of proceedings pending at the commission to address these changes to the electric grid and you can expect to see more about this in the future.
So with that, let me turn it over to Chris.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. And good morning, everyone. I'll begin my remarks with an update on our operations. And then touch on some additional regulatory developments. I'm going to start with safety, which is fundamental to the work that our crews do everyday.Over
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. And good morning, everyone. I'll begin my remarks with an update on our operations. And then touch on some additional regulatory developments. I'm going to start with safety, which is fundamental to the work that our crews do everyday.
Over the past few years, we work to create an environment where all employees feel comfortable speaking up when something doesn't look right or they identify a potential safety risk.
We were gratified to see that this was one of the areas where we received the most positive feedback in our employee survey last year. By encouraging this find it and fix it mindset, and recognizing employees who do speak up, or stop jobs when safety is a concern, we're identifying and addressing issues early. We measure ourselves on a set of safety metrics associated with both public and employee safety and you can see several others in our appendix in the slide deck.
For example, we target responding to emergency gas calls within 21 minutes. During the first quarter, we had responders on-site with an average of less than 20 minutes. That's a level of performance towards the very top of the industry.
On the electric side, we chatted improvement every year on a number of sustained outages costs by downed wires. In the first quarter of this year, our results showed a nearly 25% improvement.
Over the past 5 years, safety metrics have been an increasing component of our variable compensation plan. In gas operations, we continue to do significant work on our pipeline system, testing, replacing and automating components. For several years, we have been diligently addressing the recommendations made by the NTSB following the San Bruno accident. The NTSB disclosed 9 of the 12 recommendations. The remaining 3 recommendations which involves strength testing, valve installation and control room procedures are longer term multi-year efforts and they continue to be on track.
In electric operations, we continue to see strong reliability performance with our customers experiencing fewer and shorter outages.
In the California ISO awarded us 2 of the 3 competitive transmission projects we submitted bids last year, both of which are in our service territory.
As California enters its fourth year of drought, we're working hard to stop the state meet this challenge by reducing water usage at our own facility, encouraging customers to conserve by offering rebates for more efficient washers and agricultural pumps. We're stepping up our vegetation management activities to mitigate wildfire risk and improve access for firefighters. And we're managing water in our own hydro system to help meet the peak load this summer.
Shifting to regulatory matters. As Tony mentioned, the commission issued a $1.6 billion final penalty decision in the gas transmission pipeline investigation. And Kent will take you through the specific components of that in a minute.
The commission also announced 2 new investigations, One on regulatory communications and one on our safety culture. The work we've undertaken to improve our safety culture over the past 4.5 years has been informed by significant benchmarking and input from experts from the outside. And we look forward to the opportunities to share our progress with the commission.
Moving to the Gas Transmission and Storage Rate Case, we completed hearings in March. PG&E presented a strong case informed by a detailed risk assessment of the assets across our system.
The next steps are opening briefs, which will be filed today, and then reply brief on May 20.
The current schedule calls for a final decision in the rate case in August of 2015, with revenues retroactive to January 1. It's unclear at this point how the final penalty decision will impact the schedule. Last week, we received a proposed decision in the residential rate reform proceeding at the commission. The proposed decision acknowledges the need for fundamental rate reform and recommends reducing residential tiers from 4 to 2 over the next few years.
However, we were disappointed that it failed in the near term to adapt monthly charges to recover fixed costs. Fixed charges are a common element of many utilities rates and we continue to believe that can be implemented with minimal impact to customers, and that the time is right to adapt them in California.
We'll be filing comments on the proposed decisions in May. And finally, as we look forward in September of this year, we'll be filing our next General Rate Case, which will set forth our plans for gas and electric distribution and generation from 2017 to 2019.
So with that, I'll turn it over to Kent.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Today, I plan to cover our quarterly results, including the impact of the final penalty decision in the gas transmission pipeline investigation. I'll walk you through all of that, and then I'll spend some time on our outlook for
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Today, I plan to cover our quarterly results, including the impact of the final penalty decision in the gas transmission pipeline investigation. I'll walk you through all of that, and then I'll spend some time on our outlook for 2015.
First, our quarterly results, which were summarized on Slide 5. Earnings from operations came in at $0.87 for the quarter. GAAP earnings, including our items in impacting comparability came in at $0.06. Obviously, our items impacting comparability drove much of the story for the quarter, so let me go through those.
Our pipeline related expenses came in at $17 million pretax or $10 million after-tax as shown in the table. And here, we've included our cost to remediate encroachments on our pipeline rights-of-way. And some remaining expense work for our Pipeline Safety Enhancement Plan.
Our legal and regulatory expenses were $14 million pretax or $8 million after-tax in the table. These include costs incurred in connection with litigation and enforcement activities related to natural gas matters and regulatory communication.
Fines and penalties for the quarter totaled $553 million as shown in the table below. I'll walk you through the components of that.
First, the $300 million fine payable to the state resulted in a $100 million accrual in Q1. This is because we previously took a $200 million charge in 2011. Second, the $400 million customer bill credit was fully accrued in Q1. This reflects our obligation now to provide a credit to customers in February 2016. Third, the Q1 impacted the shareholder refunded safety improvements with a $53 million charge for disallowed capital. And I'm going to take a moment to explain that figure.
As you know, the final penalty decision calls for shareholders to fund $850 million of safety improvement to be determined in our 2015 Gas Transmission and Storage Rate Case. This will consist of about $160 million of expense work, and about $690 million of capital work.
We expect the CPUC to reduce the authorized revenues in the gas transmission rate case with these disallowed cost.
In Q1, you see nothing here for disallowed expense work. This is because of the item impacting comparability for the expense work will occur as the revenue is disallowed, not as the expenses are incurred. When we received the final decision in the Gas Transmission Rate Case, we expect to book revenues retroactive to January 1, and the impact of the revenue disallowance will redeem effectiveness in item impacting comparability and that time.
What you do see here is a $53 million charge for disallowed capital work. The item impacting comparability for capital occurs as the capital is incurred and written off.
I know that's complicated, so I'll reiterate it. This allowed expense work will show up as an item impacting comparability when the revenues are disallowed in the gas transmission rate case. Disallowed capital work will show up as an item impacting comparability when the capital is spent. 
One more thing to keep mind, the CPUC has not yet determined which cost will count towards the $850 million of shareholder funded safety work, so we've estimated which capital expenditures incurred during the quarter we think will qualify.
Once eligibility is determined in the Gas Transmission Owner Rate Case, we'll chew up any differences necessary.
Slide 6 shows our quarter-over-quarter comparison for earnings from operation. As you can see, we're going from $0.54 in Q1 last year to $0.87 in Q1 this year, and there are a number of factors. The largest impact, $0.21, is due to the 2014 General Rate Case decision which we didn't receive until August last year.
The impact includes both higher cost recovery as well as the tax benefit associated with repairs. In addition, $0.05 of the Q1 increase was due to growth in rate base earnings and another $0.05 because we had a nuclear refueling outage in Q1 of last year, but not this year.
There were $0.04 associated with tax timing. We expect that to net to 0 by year end. You also see $0.03 to the disposition of the remaining SolarCity shares and miscellaneous is about $0.05.
These positive factors were partially offset by $0.08 of lower cost recovery due to the timing of the Gas Transmission Rate Case.
The case covers cost for work we previously included as items impacting comparability, such as hydrostatic testing and integrity management. Until we are authorized revenues in the gas transmission rate case, this work will now reduce earnings from operation.
When we receive a final decision in the case, the revenue increase will be retroactive to January 1. And then finally, we had $0.02 for higher shares during the quarter.
That completes my summary of the Q1 result. And I now like to move on to our outlook going forward.
The final penalty decision result a significant uncertainty for the company, particularly with respect to the fines and penalties to be borne by shareholders and our associated financing team. Therefore, today, we are providing guidance for 2015 earnings from operation of $3.50 to $3.70 per share.
I want to spend some time going through the key assumptions underlying our guidance which are shown on Slide 7. And this should look familiar to you.
Starting in the upper left, you'll see that we're still assuming capital expenditures of roughly $5.5 billion this year, consistent with our last call. In the upper right, you'll see that our estimate of weighted average authorized rate base is still at about $31 billion. We've actually adjusted the gas transmission range down by about $200 million to reflect the estimated 2015 impacts of that capital disallowance and the final penalty decision.
Remember, this is average rate base for the year so you only see about half of the full year impact of the disallowance. In the lower left, you see there are no changes to our assumptions regarding authorized return on equity and equity ratio.
At the bottom right of the slide, we list factors we believe will affect 2015 earnings from operation. Our objective continues to be to earn our authorized return on rate base for the enterprise as a whole, plus the net impact of the factors listed here.
The first bullet under the Gas Transmission and Storage Rate Case highlights the key assumption underlying our guidance. Namely that we receive a reasonable decision in the case and that it is issued before the end of the year.
The current schedule calls for a final decision in August, but the judge has yet to determine how to address the shareholder funded safety improvement mandated in the final penalty decision. And we don't know how that could impact the schedule.
If we do not receive a final decision in the Gas Transmission Rate Case before year-end, we would not record the incremental revenues for 2015 until next year. If that were to occur, we estimate that it would reduce this year's earnings from operation by roughly $0.60 per share.
The second bullet under the rate case is the reminder that we've not thought recovery of certain corrosion at stress testing work in 2015 and beyond, and we previously indicated that these expenses, it average roughly $50 million annually over the 3-year period although the in a may vary year-over-year.
Next is the tax benefit associated with the federal repairs deduction. Last year, the net impact from this item was $0.24, and we expect it to be a similar order of magnitude this year.
After that, our -- the expense of revenue for things like our customer energy efficiency program and the impact of monetizing the remaining SolarCity shares which occurred in Q1. 
And finally, like last year, we expect earnings on construction work in progress to be roughly offset by below the line cost such as advertising, charitable contribution, environmental cost and so forth.
Slide 8 summarizes our overall guidance. At the top, you'll see our 2015 guidance for earnings from operations, that's $3.50 to $3.70 per share. Guidance for our items impacting comparability is shown below that and is broken down into the 3 category. 
We've got more detail on the lease on Slide 9, so let's go there now. And I'll start at the top. You can see that we're reaffirming the estimated range for pipeline related expenses of $100 million to $150 million. We're also reaffirming the estimated range for legal and regulatory related expenses of $25 million to $75 million.
Next, we're establishing an estimate of roughly $1 billion in 2015 for fines and penalties associated with the final decision of the gas transmission pipeline investigation. You can see the key components in the table below.
The first two, the fine payable to the state and the customer bill credit were accrued in the first quarter. We estimate that charges for disallowed capital work will come to about $350 million for the year, roughly half of the total disallowed capital. We also believe will see the full $160 million of disallowed revenues for expense work in 2015, assuming we receive a final decision in the Gas Transmission Rate Case before year end.
This estimate does not include potential fines and penalties in the future such as any revenues disallowed in the Gas Transmission Rate Case asset penalty for ex parte communication.
Slide 10 shows you how to get from this billion dollars estimate for 2015 to the total $1.6 billion of fines and penalties coming out of the gas investigation. Going from left to right, you'll see the cost incurred prior to this year. The estimated impact for 2015. And then finally, the cost we expect to incur in future periods. The future item consist of charges for the disallowed capital next year as well as remedies specified in the final decision -- or final penalty decision. 
Moving on to Slide 11. We are now estimating our total equity needs for 2015 to be between $700 million and $800 million. This range is consistent with the guidance and assumptions I've walked you through this morning.
It compares with our prior estimate of $400 million to $600 million which, of course, did not include the impact of the fines and penalties coming out of that gas investigation. As the slide indicates, the fines and penalties clearly drive up our equity needs for the year.
Going in the other direction though, our overall cash flows are a bit stronger due to items such as balancing accounts activity and timing of expenditures during the year. This is mitigated some of our equity needs for 2015.
Keep in mind that we typically issue about $300 million annually using our internal program, our 401(k) and dividend reinvestment program. In addition, we issued $75 million in the first quarter using our continuous equity offering or dribble program.
That would leave our remaining equity needs for the year at roughly $300 million to $400 million, and we're currently evaluating options for that.
By the way, we've updated the equity factors slide in the appendix to align with the components of the final penalty decision.
Slides 12 and 13 summarize our assumptions for CapEx and rate base through 2016. The CapEx numbers are the same you've seen before, and you can see that we expect 2016 to look fairly similar to 2015, depending primarily on the outcome of the Gas Transmission Rate Case. The authorized base rate numbers have been adjusted to reflect the capital disallowance resulting from the final penalty decision. The impact on 2016 average rate base is a reduction of about $500 million. Our average rate base is expected to grow to right around $33 billion in 2016, and the adjustment for the final penalty decision result at an 8% CAGR over 2014 as compared to 9% previously.
We plan to provide you with CapEx and rate base numbers beyond 2016 once we file our 2017 General Rate Case this fall.
With that, I'll stop here, and we'll now open the lines for your questions.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Steve Fleishman with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Steve Fleishman with Wolfe Research.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess this is for Kent. So I'm the equity issuance needs, and specifically these cash flows from balancing account and timing. Is there any way to kind of give us a sense of how much that lowered the equity need? And do those essentially kind of normali
componenttext: I guess this is for Kent. So I'm the equity issuance needs, and specifically these cash flows from balancing account and timing. Is there any way to kind of give us a sense of how much that lowered the equity need? And do those essentially kind of normalize back in future years, so thus there's kind of an equity need for it later on?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, let me get to that. Let me just make sure everybody's got the overall picture clearly, which is that the rate is higher than previously said because of the impact of the final penalty decision. But these other factors, mainly cash flows have s
componenttext: Yes, Steve, let me get to that. Let me just make sure everybody's got the overall picture clearly, which is that the rate is higher than previously said because of the impact of the final penalty decision. But these other factors, mainly cash flows have somewhat mitigated the overall increase. Our cash flows have improved somewhat. And those do reduce our financing requirements. And really, a key factor is within our balancing account activities. And in particular, our Energy Procurement costs which are lower, primarily due to lower gas prices. They've stayed very low this year, lower than was reflected in previous expectations. And then the other thing is really kind of timing of our CapEx and our other expenditures. And together, those really improve the cash flow and forecast to reduce our requirement. Those will essentially normalize over time and play out over -- what is usually a several year period, particularly balancing accounts stuff gets chewed up usually over a several year period.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe kind of asking the question in a different way. Is there a way to give a sense of if you looked at the totality of the $1.6 billion and didn't focus on the exact timing of the equity needs? But you said, overall, the equity would be to find th
componenttext: Okay. Maybe kind of asking the question in a different way. Is there a way to give a sense of if you looked at the totality of the $1.6 billion and didn't focus on the exact timing of the equity needs? But you said, overall, the equity would be to find the $1.6 billion?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The key thing I would rely on is Slide 20 that has our equity factors. I think you'll be able to essentially take the components in the final penalty decision and translate them into financing requirements. And I'll just say, we haven't provided guid
componenttext: Yes. The key thing I would rely on is Slide 20 that has our equity factors. I think you'll be able to essentially take the components in the final penalty decision and translate them into financing requirements. And I'll just say, we haven't provided guidance for equity issuance beyond this year, and I don't plan to today. But I'll kind of -- I can give you some observations about it overall. I think you know our equity needs are a function of a lot of variables in any 1 period. But the key ones are our capital expenditure levels, and our unrecovered cost and penalties. And that latter one can affect our -- both our capital structure and our cash flow. And so it can trigger equity needs at different times, and that's really what this Slide 20 helps you sort through. In terms of those 2 factors, I'll just make the observation on the CapEx front. We expect 2016 to be pretty comparable to 2015, and you have those numbers. In terms of the penalty, we estimate that about 2/3 of our equity needs associated with the final penalty decision will be addressed this year as compared to next year. And you should be able to derive that using the equity factors that we've put in Slide 20. The only other thing I'll say, I'll just remind you that all of this depends on how that disallowed safety-related expense end up being treated in that gas transmission rate case, and we just won't do that for a while yet.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. One other question, I guess, maybe more for Tony. Just the -- there was a lot of commentary when the final San Bruno order came out about issues with management and kind of whether the company should stay as 1 company, should the gas business be spl
componenttext: Okay. One other question, I guess, maybe more for Tony. Just the -- there was a lot of commentary when the final San Bruno order came out about issues with management and kind of whether the company should stay as 1 company, should the gas business be split. Anything, kind of takeaways that you might have from that? And also, just like any comments on just clarifying what happened with the fire that occurred in Fresno? And just clarifying kind of whether you're seeing anything within your operations that concern you about that?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take the first base, and I'll let Chris talk about the Fresno event. So with respect to the first issue, the commentary around the issuance of the OII. Clearly, it held us -- we had a lot of work to do to build trust and relationship at the co
componenttext: Yes, let me take the first base, and I'll let Chris talk about the Fresno event. So with respect to the first issue, the commentary around the issuance of the OII. Clearly, it held us -- we had a lot of work to do to build trust and relationship at the commission. And we've had restrictions placed on us, but it's our intent to have the maximum amount of communications with the commission at all levels that are appropriate, consistent with all of the restrictions, and that's one of the things we know we need to work on. We're proud of the work we've done, and we think we need to spend more time sharing some of the things that we've done. And time will tell whether were able to develop that sort of trusting relationship. With that, let me ask Chris to comment on the incident that occurred in Fresno.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, Steve. First of all, our hearts are out for the victims that are the folks that were injured there. And we always are concerned about making sure that we're doing what we can to increase our public safety. Obviously, we did not have anybody that was o
componenttext: Hi, Steve. First of all, our hearts are out for the victims that are the folks that were injured there. And we always are concerned about making sure that we're doing what we can to increase our public safety. Obviously, we did not have anybody that was on site when the accident occurred. And so we don't know exactly what happened. But we do know some things. First of all, we do know that there was no 811 call made for the -- for that area where work was being done. We do know that there were a couple of pipeline markers in place right around where the accident occurred. We do know that there was first move in construction equipment that was precedent at the time of the incident. Also we know that we've surveyed that area several times over the last several months, we do it about every 2 weeks, both with walking by and if I ever. And in fact, we had photos from the day before when we had last surveyed that, and we did not see any construction going on at that time. So we've been -- word with the CPUC release of the lead regulatory agency on this item. And on the investigation as to what happened. And they've authorized us to higher exponent, who is a third party to perform a thorough analysis of the damaged pipe so that we can determine exactly what did happen there, and that will be available in the next month or so. So that's where we're at with that.

componenttext: Well, we honestly recognize dividend is an important piece of how shareholders value us, and it's my intention to start having those discussions with our board. And as I said in the past, my focus is to get our payout ratio in line with those of our peers. Obviously, we'll have to talk about the timing with our board, but we're going to be starting those discussions. We'll take some time to take all the variables into account. But we understand that's very important.

componenttext: Okay. And I guess one last question. When you guys filed the GRC, the next GRC, how will you guys incorporate the Grid of Things type of spending priorities in that budget? Will they be included in at that point in time? Or you think you need to see more clarity after the July 1 filing before you start to put them into the formal capital something?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Chris. We will start that process. We are doing our annual planning process, which is to look out every 5 years. And so there's some beginning of that spend during that 5-year plan on the Grid of Things, and that will feed into what we have i
componenttext: Dan, this is Chris. We will start that process. We are doing our annual planning process, which is to look out every 5 years. And so there's some beginning of that spend during that 5-year plan on the Grid of Things, and that will feed into what we have in the GRC. I didn't think in this GRC it will see some huge explosion of investments there, but you said to see some investments in some of the ideas though. Don't forget, we've already made huge investment in our Grid of Things with our smart meter program and with a lot of the switches, the Cornerstone Program. A lot of that has already laid in the foundation from where we're going to go with it.

Is any of corrosion, hydro sync stuff in there? Or is any of the cost of something delayed 5 months? Are any of those things in the something?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, they're not. So these are the components that were included in the CPUC spinal penalty decision. I separately went through and the guidance for our items impacting comparability. The impact of the rights-of-way work as well as there's some remaining p
componenttext: No, they're not. So these are the components that were included in the CPUC spinal penalty decision. I separately went through and the guidance for our items impacting comparability. The impact of the rights-of-way work as well as there's some remaining piece of work. And I also indicated in the guidance, our earnings from operations, the assumptions there that the additional gas related cost that we've not felt recovery for, which are certain corrosion work as well as certain hydrostatic testing work that we expected that to average about $50 million a year for each of the 3 years that, that would be embedded in our earnings from operation.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, right, right. I developed this. I just want to be crystal clear that it's included. So is there anyway you can put a number holistically if we -- you keep referring us to Slide 20, but I guess 2 things that I didn't appreciate that $200 million of
componenttext: Right, right, right. I developed this. I just want to be crystal clear that it's included. So is there anyway you can put a number holistically if we -- you keep referring us to Slide 20, but I guess 2 things that I didn't appreciate that $200 million of the $300 million fine, that will not need equity issuance, right? Because that's already -- since you already took hit for that. You don't need equity issuance, that's number one. And number two, so is there any way to put the amount of dollars for this cash flow benefit from balance of that account?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me parse through those 2. In the first comment, you made with your conclusion that we don't need equity needs associated with the first $200 million that we accrued awhile back. That's actually not quite the case. And when you look at the equity fa
componenttext: So let me parse through those 2. In the first comment, you made with your conclusion that we don't need equity needs associated with the first $200 million that we accrued awhile back. That's actually not quite the case. And when you look at the equity factors, because today, that's been a noncash accrual. Roughly half of that, essentially has been financed. And the remaining half get financed at the time we actually pay the fine. So there is some remaining need that comes from that fine payables, the original $200 million. What was the second part of your question again?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The second part was, is there a way to predict the dollar amount undiscussed will benefit from regulatory? From balancing?
componenttext: The second part was, is there a way to predict the dollar amount undiscussed will benefit from regulatory? From balancing?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: What I would suggest is when you think about, go to our old guidance for equity, look at -- which do not include any of the equity needs associated with the final penalty decision. You'll see equity factors on Slide 20 to estimate what the incremental equ
componenttext: What I would suggest is when you think about, go to our old guidance for equity, look at -- which do not include any of the equity needs associated with the final penalty decision. You'll see equity factors on Slide 20 to estimate what the incremental equity needs are. And there'll be a difference between that and the guidance that we're currently giving you for our overall equity needs, and one of the key drivers of that will be the factors related to cash flow.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Lapides from Goldman Sachs.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: One question about 2015 guidance. If you just, like, back of the envelope, rate base map, I'll use Greg Gordon's algebra for an example here. If I'll do $31 billion out of 52% equity ratio, and at a 10 4 authorized ROE, using your current share count, I get a number that's actually below your guidance range. So can you just walk me through what the Delta there is? And then does that Delta, does that different gear to continue kind of multiple years going forward? Or is that something that's 2015 event only?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so this is Kent. I suggest you focus on Slide 7. And on Slide 7, essentially, the map you just went through, is for all intensive purposes. The upper part of the chart and the number and the lower left of the chart, you did the math on it. The other
componenttext: Yes, so this is Kent. I suggest you focus on Slide 7. And on Slide 7, essentially, the map you just went through, is for all intensive purposes. The upper part of the chart and the number and the lower left of the chart, you did the math on it. The other part go is the lower right part of the chart. The other factors affecting our earnings from operations. And I sort of gave commentary on each of those factors. The biggest driver is related to the net benefit of the repairs, the tax benefit. And we've indicated that we would expect that this year to have an impact that's comparable, same order of magnitude from last year when it was $0.24 a share.

componenttext: Okay, and beyond this year, meaning, that stops after in 2016? Or does that carry forward in the '16 and beyond?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Hugh Wynne from AllianceBernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Hugh Wynne from AllianceBernstein.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to get some clarity on the pending investigations and cases that may result in future fines. And perhaps, get your view on the similar amount of those fines. Is it correct to say that we have the federal case, the ex parte withholding of GT&S
componenttext: I was hoping to get some clarity on the pending investigations and cases that may result in future fines. And perhaps, get your view on the similar amount of those fines. Is it correct to say that we have the federal case, the ex parte withholding of GT&S revenue, is the OII into the safety records and I guess distribution side? And then the investigation into the safety OII into the safety culture of PG&E? Or are there other investigations and cases we need to be aware of in addition to those 4?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hugh, I think that covers the list that we're aware of. I'm looking at Hyun Park, our General Counsel, I think he actually covers that.
componenttext: Hugh, I think that covers the list that we're aware of. I'm looking at Hyun Park, our General Counsel, I think he actually covers that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You and Tony mentioned earlier that something as well as the federal prosecutors are looking at the ex parte. So that's -- investigation is still ongoing.
componenttext: You and Tony mentioned earlier that something as well as the federal prosecutors are looking at the ex parte. So that's -- investigation is still ongoing.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just kind of -- is it bigger than the buyback step of estimates here, the maximum penalty and the federal case, I think the federal attorney said, the issue was seeking up to $1.1 billion, is that correct? Is there any color you can give us
componenttext: Okay. And then just kind of -- is it bigger than the buyback step of estimates here, the maximum penalty and the federal case, I think the federal attorney said, the issue was seeking up to $1.1 billion, is that correct? Is there any color you can give us on that?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's $1.13 billion, is what they've alleged. And the color is that we disagree with that.
componenttext: Yes, so it's $1.13 billion, is what they've alleged. And the color is that we disagree with that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And remember, the $1.13 billion is the alternative fine provision where you calculate either gain that we got for losses that were incurred. But of course, with respect to that, we settled all of the civil cases. So there, arguably, there are no losses le
componenttext: And remember, the $1.13 billion is the alternative fine provision where you calculate either gain that we got for losses that were incurred. But of course, with respect to that, we settled all of the civil cases. So there, arguably, there are no losses left to cover. Certainly, there wasn't gain to the company. I mean, look at the size of this penalty. You know there was no gain to the company. So if you go back to the fundamental provisions of the Pipeline Safety Act, under which that case was brought, the fines, I think, are $500,000 account and there are 20 some accounts and so you can run the numbers that way as we believe would be a more likely -- if, in fact, there is liability, which, of course, we contest are fairly strong.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you're basically pushing us the direction of a nominal fine, maybe a $1 million because of the inability to apply the something metrics for a larger fine?
componenttext: Okay. So you're basically pushing us the direction of a nominal fine, maybe a $1 million because of the inability to apply the something metrics for a larger fine?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So few, if you do the math under the more conventional fine method, it's $500,000 per account, 28 accounts, so that adds up to, I believe, $14 million. And they've alleged the bonds, which Tony described. And by the way, some of this is discussed and some
componenttext: So few, if you do the math under the more conventional fine method, it's $500,000 per account, 28 accounts, so that adds up to, I believe, $14 million. And they've alleged the bonds, which Tony described. And by the way, some of this is discussed and some of the motions we filed on Monday, so you can see some of the discussion of that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the ex parte communication, is it correct to say that the CPUC is still reserving the right to withhold approximately $230 million from the GT&S revenue? Or is there some new benchmark there?
componenttext: On the ex parte communication, is it correct to say that the CPUC is still reserving the right to withhold approximately $230 million from the GT&S revenue? Or is there some new benchmark there?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hugh, this is Kent. I think what they said that they would find us up to 5 months of whatever the ultimate revenue increase is coming out of the cases, we don't know what that is yet.
componenttext: Hugh, this is Kent. I think what they said that they would find us up to 5 months of whatever the ultimate revenue increase is coming out of the cases, we don't know what that is yet.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. So that's still -- the final determination is still pending, but it could be 5 months of GT&S revenue increase since the case?
componenttext: Right. So that's still -- the final determination is still pending, but it could be 5 months of GT&S revenue increase since the case?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That will be determined at the end of the case.
componenttext: That will be determined at the end of the case.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the distribution safety, OII, are there any parameters we can use? Should we make reference to the OII into the transmission system? Or is this going to be a different order of magnitude?
componenttext: On the distribution safety, OII, are there any parameters we can use? Should we make reference to the OII into the transmission system? Or is this going to be a different order of magnitude?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's one. The case is just getting into a -- we can't even give you an order of magnitude of what might come out of that. If, in fact, there is any liability at all.
componenttext: That's one. The case is just getting into a -- we can't even give you an order of magnitude of what might come out of that. If, in fact, there is any liability at all.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And what about the OII and the safety culture? That seems a very intangible OII demand. I wonder is it-- do we expect penalties to be soft there? Or is that a different type of investigation?
componenttext: And what about the OII and the safety culture? That seems a very intangible OII demand. I wonder is it-- do we expect penalties to be soft there? Or is that a different type of investigation?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And again, it's very early. I mean, the way I heard it, it sounds like a different type of investigation around what we've done with respect to our safety culture. And as I've said before, that's an area we actually feel very good about. We've spent a lot
componenttext: And again, it's very early. I mean, the way I heard it, it sounds like a different type of investigation around what we've done with respect to our safety culture. And as I've said before, that's an area we actually feel very good about. We've spent a lot of effort on safety culture issues starting with doing some very significant benchmarking of other companies to look at what they do. And I will tell you that we've learned a lot from that benchmark. But we also learned that we compare quite favorably to our peers with respect to what were doing. We hired a number of third-party experts to come in and look at safety culture from a former head of the NTSB to Lloyd's Registry in London, who's done work under ISO 55000. And things like changing our disciplined policy to encourage employees to identify safety issues to a program to identify near hits as we call them on safety, that has greatly expanded our understanding of where the risk are in the company. And a number of other things, training of all of our leaders on safety cultures. So we've done a lot. It hasn't shown up in specific proceedings. And we think this will be an opportunity, at some point, when the OII gets underway to talk about what we've done.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one final question. Are you considering as a matter of strategy trying to settle these various cases and investigations so that the hit to equity can be known or to the best interest of shareholders, just kind of fight this out to the bitte
componenttext: Okay. And just one final question. Are you considering as a matter of strategy trying to settle these various cases and investigations so that the hit to equity can be known or to the best interest of shareholders, just kind of fight this out to the bitter end? Or let the process takes its course?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that would -- our recent decision show is, we want to aggressively defend the shareholders' interest. But at some point, certainty is in the shareholders' interest, and that was kind of behind our decision not to appeal the San Bruno OIIs. Even th
componenttext: I think that would -- our recent decision show is, we want to aggressively defend the shareholders' interest. But at some point, certainty is in the shareholders' interest, and that was kind of behind our decision not to appeal the San Bruno OIIs. Even though there were some issues we thought might be appealable. In the end, it was better to have certainty, so we can continue to focus on improving the system. We are always open to settlements in these cases. We're not open to admitting the things that just didn't occur, and it gets our position and the criminal case that we don't see anyone who didn't -- who made any intentional decisions to violate the Pipeline Safety Act, but we will continue to look for opportunities to get second-tier by resolving some of these proceedings.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Weinstein with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Weinstein with UBS.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk about, what's the normalized tax rate that you expect to have in the next GRC once the repair benefits are absorbed?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk about, what's the normalized tax rate that you expect to have in the next GRC once the repair benefits are absorbed?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Dinyar, I am the Controller. We expect the repairs flowthrough rate making to continue in the next General Rate Case, and so it should have a similar order of magnitude on our effective tax rate. What you have been seeing in this year, the 20% tha
componenttext: This is Dinyar, I am the Controller. We expect the repairs flowthrough rate making to continue in the next General Rate Case, and so it should have a similar order of magnitude on our effective tax rate. What you have been seeing in this year, the 20% that Kent mentioned is the difference between the precipitous forecasted -- that a person who are experiencing to file that tax return, that should be chewed up in the 2017 rate case.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And once it's chewed up, will with the feminist tax rate be? The 35% or no?
componenttext: Right. And once it's chewed up, will with the feminist tax rate be? The 35% or no?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: 35% is the statutory rate. If you go to our financial statement at the end of last year, you will see that our effective rate was roughly 20% rate. And it should be probably similar. I don't know how it's going to shakeout because it is a technical calcul
componenttext: 35% is the statutory rate. If you go to our financial statement at the end of last year, you will see that our effective rate was roughly 20% rate. And it should be probably similar. I don't know how it's going to shakeout because it is a technical calculation, but it does not mean that there's a benefit to the bottom line because there's an associated reduction on the revenue side.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I see. So you will be effectively earning at the 35% rate even if your cap rate is 20%?
componenttext: I see. So you will be effectively earning at the 35% rate even if your cap rate is 20%?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think a better way to think about it is that, there is no benefit or harm from the effective tax rate being different from the statutory tax rate, it's just a calculation.
componenttext: I think a better way to think about it is that, there is no benefit or harm from the effective tax rate being different from the statutory tax rate, it's just a calculation.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fine of that. Another question is about the future CapEx, growth profile after 2016. You had asked and the call comedy discussed kind of having a flat profile over the next decade and $1 billion level. And that includes, presumably -- it might exclu
componenttext: Okay, fine of that. Another question is about the future CapEx, growth profile after 2016. You had asked and the call comedy discussed kind of having a flat profile over the next decade and $1 billion level. And that includes, presumably -- it might exclude the benefits that might come from investing in the distribution resource plan that's coming out in July. So I'm just wondering if you guys have a similar view of the next decade, especially considering the EV filing that your CapEx profile will be growing or would it kind of be flattish over the next decade? Or not?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Kent. We will be providing you with numbers when get to the fall. I would say, our observation is that, we are doing a lot of infrastructure investment. Essentially, hardening our system, replacing a lot of stuff that was put in post-World War II
componenttext: This is Kent. We will be providing you with numbers when get to the fall. I would say, our observation is that, we are doing a lot of infrastructure investment. Essentially, hardening our system, replacing a lot of stuff that was put in post-World War II and so forth. And we don't expect that program to finish. By the time we're done with 2016. So we'll continue to see come I think, I have the campus profile going forward. But we're not prepared to actually provide you numbers at this point until we finish up GRC filing.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Chin with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Chin with Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: Is there an implied timing of the equity issuance embedded in the '15 guidance that you can give a little more color on?

componenttext: No, there isn't. As I've indicated before, we're still evaluating our options for the financing, and that's with respect about the timing and the approach.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Travis Miller with MorningStar.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Travis Miller with MorningStar.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just feel a lot of talk, plenty of talk about the equity side. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the credit side and timing there in terms of issues and needs?
componenttext: I just feel a lot of talk, plenty of talk about the equity side. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the credit side and timing there in terms of issues and needs?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Travis, this is Kent again. I think if you look last year, our net debt issuance was about $1.4 billion, that set of maturity. And as probably not far off from what we've done from the last several years, so I would say similar order of magnitude gi
componenttext: Well, Travis, this is Kent again. I think if you look last year, our net debt issuance was about $1.4 billion, that set of maturity. And as probably not far off from what we've done from the last several years, so I would say similar order of magnitude given similar CapEx program is a little bit higher CapEx this year. So similar profile, but we're not going to be talking about timing to were -- closer to actually starting a transaction.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Remind me real quick. When do you need to have the capital structure in place for rate making purposes? What's the timing on that?
componenttext: Remind me real quick. When do you need to have the capital structure in place for rate making purposes? What's the timing on that?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's essentially over the period during which the capital structure is authorized. So for us, it's over this cost of capital period, which has been, essentially will end up being a 4-year period right now.
componenttext: Yes. It's essentially over the period during which the capital structure is authorized. So for us, it's over this cost of capital period, which has been, essentially will end up being a 4-year period right now.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other real quick one. Talk about the tax deductions and debate there with the CPUC. If they were to disallow some of that tax right off, how does that change that Slide 20?
componenttext: One other real quick one. Talk about the tax deductions and debate there with the CPUC. If they were to disallow some of that tax right off, how does that change that Slide 20?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Dinyar Mistry again, the Controller. And let's just go through the components of the penalty that you see on Slide 20. And if you look at that, the fine table to the state general fund is not tax-deductible. But we continue to believe the other di
componenttext: This is Dinyar Mistry again, the Controller. And let's just go through the components of the penalty that you see on Slide 20. And if you look at that, the fine table to the state general fund is not tax-deductible. But we continue to believe the other disallowances included in the commission's final decision are tax deduction.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Goldenberg with Luminous Management.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Goldenberg with Luminous Management.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to confirm. When you guys talk about equity issue, do you just talk about straight equity? Or are you considering other options?
componenttext: I just wanted to confirm. When you guys talk about equity issue, do you just talk about straight equity? Or are you considering other options?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Kent. And we are, in general, as you know for this unrecovered fines and penalties, we've been saying that primarily, we're relying on equity issuance. And over the past couple of years, I've had conversations with investors and certainly
componenttext: Michael, this is Kent. And we are, in general, as you know for this unrecovered fines and penalties, we've been saying that primarily, we're relying on equity issuance. And over the past couple of years, I've had conversations with investors and certainly with you about options, such as mandatory converts, for example. But I will say at this point, I think that option is probably less likely now. Just given the size of our remaining equity need for this year.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Monique, I think we have time for 1 more question.
componenttext: Monique, I think we have time for 1 more question.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of John Smyth from something management.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of John Smyth from something management.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael asked my question, but I just wanted you to elaborate a little bit more on the equity needs for 2015 and your options. I mean, you have a $300 million drift, and can you remind us of the size of the ATM program that you have in place?
componenttext: Michael asked my question, but I just wanted you to elaborate a little bit more on the equity needs for 2015 and your options. I mean, you have a $300 million drift, and can you remind us of the size of the ATM program that you have in place?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we -- the equity options that we have used in the past include our internal programs which are both driven the 401(k) program. We typically have issued roughly $300 million a year from those program. We have had a continuous equity offering and we
componenttext: Yes, so we -- the equity options that we have used in the past include our internal programs which are both driven the 401(k) program. We typically have issued roughly $300 million a year from those program. We have had a continuous equity offering and we have a program there for $500 million, and I believe in the first quarter, we did approximately $80 million of that through the programs. So those are the 2 components you are relying on, are you referencing.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So between the continuous equity and the drift program, you have $800 million of total capacity? Is that the right way to look at it?
componenttext: So between the continuous equity and the drift program, you have $800 million of total capacity? Is that the right way to look at it?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct. Of course, the continuous equity offering is not limited to $500 million, that's just our current program. And we've actually renewed that program several times over the last 2 years.
componenttext: That's correct. Of course, the continuous equity offering is not limited to $500 million, that's just our current program. And we've actually renewed that program several times over the last 2 years.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then regarding these balancing account, can you quantify these at all as far as the cash impact?
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then regarding these balancing account, can you quantify these at all as far as the cash impact?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think I've had several folks take around me on this call. And I think I pretty much laid out how you can get rough estimates as a various factors are driving our equity previously on the Q&A, and I'll already indicated.
componenttext: I think I've had several folks take around me on this call. And I think I pretty much laid out how you can get rough estimates as a various factors are driving our equity previously on the Q&A, and I'll already indicated.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I was just looking at your net receivable balance for the balancing accounts and it's $1.2 billion in 2014, much higher than it was in 2013. So is it right to look at it as a big cash outflow in 2014 and that is reversing in 2015? And then once that
componenttext: Well, I was just looking at your net receivable balance for the balancing accounts and it's $1.2 billion in 2014, much higher than it was in 2013. So is it right to look at it as a big cash outflow in 2014 and that is reversing in 2015? And then once that net receivable goes to 0, it's not necessarily a net cash outflow next year, right? It just stays at 0? Is that right way to look at it?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There are a lot of factors and complexity in all of our values balancing accounts. So I think actually, if you're starting with those numbers on the balance sheet, you can spend a lot of time trying to figure out the timing during which different ones amo
componenttext: There are a lot of factors and complexity in all of our values balancing accounts. So I think actually, if you're starting with those numbers on the balance sheet, you can spend a lot of time trying to figure out the timing during which different ones amortized. And I'm not sure that really need to be. So I would suggest a simpler way, is to go back to our prior estimates of equity, look at the new estimates of equity and look at our equity factors for the fines and penalties, and you'll at least know how much the equity factors are driving the change from our prior estimates to our new estimate. And any difference you see there, I've indicated on the call as significant driver that has been our cash flow forecast.
