componenttext: Okay, understood. Secondly, on the cost of capital mechanism and proceedings that will come up next year, it seems like, mechanically, the numbers are shaping out where an extension, perhaps, may not be too difficult of a suggestion to different stakeholders. I guess what I'm wondering is, are you aware of any issues out there that may prevent some of the stakeholders from wanting to consider an extension of the current mechanism? Any issues that may need to be worked through that could prevent that and instead make a full-blown cost of capital proceeding to take place?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Kent. So as you alluded to the normal process would have to file a cost of capital allocation next spring, and that will be for rates effective January 2017. And I think what you're alluding to, I think everybody knows that last year we and
componenttext: Brian, this is Kent. So as you alluded to the normal process would have to file a cost of capital allocation next spring, and that will be for rates effective January 2017. And I think what you're alluding to, I think everybody knows that last year we and the other parties all agreed to extend the existing cost of capital as well as trigger mechanism by one year. And so the question is will that happen again this year, and I just say we're open to exploring that again given that, as you said, forecast bond rates haven't changed all that much since the proceeding was originally litigated. But whether or not that occurs depends on the extent to which all of the parties are able to reach an agreement.

componenttext: Generally, we don't comment on specifics on M&A opportunities. I will say, one interesting observation, though, everything is buying a gas company. We've already got 4.5 million gas customers. I think we're in pretty good shape.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as the 350 really one of the primary components of it is the RPS requirements in the state. And generally, we have already been on track to meet the 33% RPS. This would take us now to 50% eventually. We do that primarily through long-term contractin
componenttext: Well, as the 350 really one of the primary components of it is the RPS requirements in the state. And generally, we have already been on track to meet the 33% RPS. This would take us now to 50% eventually. We do that primarily through long-term contracting. So it doesn't have a direct implication for our own CapEx, which are primarily our distribution and transmission businesses.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Although I will add one place we may see some opportunities is in additional transmission out there. We've been successful in the competitive transmission bidding process here in California in the last couple of years. We continue to intend to stay involved in that process. But all of that is outside any of the years that we've been showing on the slides because recall that the current period 3% is a 2020 objective. And so the new SB350 requirements will start showing up in the 2020 you see new transmission in that time frame. So I think the only conclusion you can draw is given California's commitment to clean energy environment is going to require the utilities to have continued investment to upgrade the system.

componenttext: Yes, we continue to look at those opportunities. I think I've said this before. The California affiliate rules make it very difficult to start from scratch because there's -- it's very hard to take your utility expertise. And without taking away from the utility and moving them to a totally separate company and again even talk to their colleagues back to your old business, it's hard to justify when we've got so many growth opportunities in the utility right now.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. This is Janet Loduca, and thank you for joining us for the Pacific Gas and Electric Corporation's Third Quarter Earnings Call. Before I turn it over to Tony Earley, I want to remind you that our discussion today will include forwar
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. This is Janet Loduca, and thank you for joining us for the Pacific Gas and Electric Corporation's Third Quarter Earnings Call. Before I turn it over to Tony Earley, I want to remind you that our discussion today will include forward-looking statements about our outlook for future financial results, which is based on assumptions, forecasts, expectations and information currently available to management. Some of the important factors that could affect the company's actual financial results are described on the second page of today's slide deck. We also encourage you to review the Form 10-Q that will be filed with the SEC later today and the discussion of risk factors that appears there and in the 2014 annual report. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Tony.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Janet, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Our key focus areas remain unchanged. California continues to lead the U.S. in driving clean energy policies, and PG&E will play a critical role in helping to achieve the state's goals.
componenttext:
Thank you, Janet, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Our key focus areas remain unchanged. California continues to lead the U.S. in driving clean energy policies, and PG&E will play a critical role in helping to achieve the state's goals. We also know that safety must be at the core of all of our decisions, and our commitment to that is unwavering.
We continue to make progress towards resolving outstanding regulatory and legal issues while strengthening our safety and compliance programs. We believe that executing our strategies in these focus areas will provide the foundation for both operational and financial success. So I want to touch on some of the key developments this quarter before I turn it over to Kent to discuss our financial results. Geisha Williams and Nick Stavropoulos are also with us today, and they'll be available to take any questions that you have. In terms of our focus on clean energy.  PG&E has a long history of action on climate change, and we've been a vocal advocate for policies that will move it forward. In fact, I recently participated in a meeting with President Obama to talk about the actions PG&E is taking to help drive clean energy policy and greenhouse gas reductions. We supported Governor Brown's recent move to increase the renewable energy target to 50% by 2030, and we're confident that we can get there.
We've been investing in the electric grid to enable both utility scale renewable and the growing distributed resources such as rooftop solar, electric vehicles and energy storage. During the quarter, we filed our proposal to update the current net metering rates. Our proposal supports the continued growth of rooftop solar while beginning the transition to a sustainable rate structure that also supports the necessary grid investments.
Our 2017 General Rate Case includes detailed proposal for continued grid modernization to ensure that we have the visibility and flexibility we'll need to enable all of the new distributed resources. Our General Rate Case also supports our goal on delivering customer expectations by providing customers with safe, reliable and affordable service.
Using a risk-based approach, we propose safety related investments across the system including replacing aging infrastructure, taking targeted actions to reduce risk and improving our emergency response. And we balance the necessary investments with affordability. Average residential bills will increase less than 3% and will remain below the national average.
In terms of reliability, the most significant event this quarter was fires in Northern California. As you know, California is in its fourth year of severe drought, and we've been partnering throughout the year with CAL FIRE and other stakeholders to address the challenging fire season. Our efforts have included things like increased patrols in vegetation management as well as enhanced emergency response coordination. At one point, the state was simultaneously fighting 3 major wildfires across 300,000 acres of our service territory. In addition to restoring power to impacted customers, our crews came up with creative ways to meet our communities' needs in a very challenging time. So for example, we leveraged the new explorable power technology from our electric trucks to provide an evacuation shelter with backup electricity when its generator failed. The response from our customers and other stakeholders has been positive, and we're really proud of how safely and quickly our crews were able to perform the work.
As we publicly reported, CAL FIRE is investigating whether one of our electric lines could potentially have been the source of the big fire. That investigation is still underway and could take quite a while to complete. So we don't have any updates on that at this time.
On the heels of the state's historic drought, we're now hearing forecast about an El Niño winter, which could bring significant rainfall and cause mudslides and floods. Our team has been preparing for this possibility through a wide array of actions including updating our meteorological models and performing drills that simulate potential flood scenarios.
Finally, in terms of resolving outstanding regulatory issues, we recently received a report from the Safety and Enforcement Division on the gas distribution recordkeeping investigation. While the report identified a number of potential past violations, which we'll be responding to in the next month. We were pleased to see that also acknowledged the progress we've made to improve our records. Over the last 2 years, we've implemented a number of new procedures that have been informed by extensive benchmarking and industry best practices. As we said from the beginning, we know we have more work to do to enhance our distribution records and practices, and we're absolutely committed to getting that right.
Geisha and Nick recently had a chance to share some of the actions we've taken to improve our safety culture at the California Public Utilities Commission's first ever safety en banc. This was an opportunity for all 5 commissioners, the presidents of California's investor-owned utilities and a number of interveners to talk about what each of the utilities is currently doing around safety and what changes the commission might make to better incorporate safety into its proceedings. Nick and Geisha talked about the changes made by our Board of Directors to focus on safety, the strong link between our executive compensation programs and safety performance, our use of third-party experts in benchmarking and the way we engage our frontline crews around safety. The commission also had the opportunity here from other utilities and to start thinking about how to create common metrics to track and measure progress. I can tell you that we thought it was a really positive step forward in the conversation, and we look forward to continuing the dialogue with all the parties.
So before I turn this over to Kent, I just want to take a moment to thank him for all that he's done for PG&E. As you know, after 33 years with the company, Kent has decided to retire next year. Kent has done a tremendous job managing PG&E's financial activities during challenges that were some of the most complex in our industry. He's also been a great source of leadership and inspiration across the company. We're working through the succession process right now, and I'm thankful that Kent has agreed to stay on to ensure a smooth transition.
So thank you, Kent. And with that, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony. Good morning, everyone. I plan to first cover our results for the quarter, and then I'll go through our updated guidance. Let me say upfront that the complexity of our rate case timing issues has made it especially difficult for you to fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony. Good morning, everyone. I plan to first cover our results for the quarter, and then I'll go through our updated guidance. Let me say upfront that the complexity of our rate case timing issues has made it especially difficult for you to forecast quarterly results. However, we do expect solid results for the full year, and you'll see that when I get to guidance.
So I'll start with our quarterly results, which is on Slide 5. Earnings from operations were $0.84 in the third quarter and GAAP earnings, including our items impacting comparability, were $0.63. Our pipeline-related expenses in the quarter were $32 million pretax or $19 million after-tax shown in the table. This includes our cost to remediate encroachments on our pipeline  rights-of-way and to complete the remaining expense work for our pipeline safety enhancement plan. Our legal and regulatory-related expenses in the quarter were $14 million pretax or $8 million after-tax in the table, and here we have our costs for litigation and enforcement activities related to natural gas matters and regulatory communications.
Fines and penalties in the quarter were $142 million pretax as shown in the table below. This amount represents the disallowed capital work coming out of the final San Bruno penalty decision, which were accruing as we do the work.
Finally, we received insurance recoveries in the quarter of $10 million pretax or $6 million after-tax as shown in the table above. I'm pleased that we now resolved all San Bruno claims with our insurance carriers; and in total, we recovered $515 million through insurance.
Moving to Slide 6. You'll see our quarter-over-quarter comparison of earnings from operations of $1.73 in Q3 last year and $0.84 in Q3 this year, and this is where it gets a little complicated due to all the timing issues. In Q3 last year, we've recorded 3 quarters’ worth of revenue increase associated with our 2014 General Rate Case. That's the biggest difference from Q3 of last year worth $0.47. $0.16 is associated with lower-cost recovery this year due to the timing of the gas transmission rate case. As you know, a lot of our transmission work is seasonal and the Q3 amount reflects a higher level of activity in the summer months. When we receive a final decision in the case next year, the revenue increase will be retroactive to January 1, 2015.
$0.09 relates to the timing of taxes, which reversed to 0 by year-end. $0.05 relates to regulatory and legal matters. This includes the impact of some favorable regulatory decisions in Q3 of last year as well as some legal costs incurred in Q3 of this year. Another $0.05 is associated with an increase in shares outstanding, and the impact here on share count is magnified by the fact that earnings in Q3 last year were so much higher as a result of booking 3 quarters’ worth of revenue increase to the GRC. $0.03 relates to the disposition of SolarCity stock in Q3 last year and $0.09 relates to a variety of smaller miscellaneous items, many of which are timing. And we've had positive miscellaneous items in previous quarters. These factors are partially offset by a $0.05 increase due to growth in rate base earnings. That's it for our Q3 results.
On Slide 7, you'll see our 2015 guidance. Previously, we've had a guidance range for earnings from operations of $2.90 to $3.10. Year-to-date, we've been trending towards the upper end of this range. Therefore, today, we're narrowing our range to between $3 and $3.10. There are few other changes to this slide. We've reduced our range for pipeline-related expenses, and I'll say more about that in a moment. We've also updated our insurance recoveries just to reflect the amount we recovered in the quarter. Our resulting GAAP guidance is shown at the bottom of the table.
On Slide 8, we've updated our 2015 CapEx assumptions from $5.5 billion previously to $5.3 billion. There are really 2 main reasons for this update: First, our response to the recent wildfires displaced some of our planned work in electric operations. And second, we're realizing some efficiencies in gas operations, primarily related to our distribution pipe replacement program. The other assumptions for 2015 on this slide remain consistent with what we've previously provided.
Slide 9 reflects the updated range for pipeline-related expenses that I mentioned earlier. You can see we've decreased the upper end of that range from $150 million to $125 million. The lower end remains at $100 million. You'll recall that this item is primarily associated with our rights-of-way work, and we continue to expect that the cost of the overall program will not exceed $500 million.
Moving on to Slide 10. Our total equity needs for 2015 remain the same at $700 million to $800 million. Through the end of Q3, we've issued roughly $700 million of equity. This includes about $350 million through a block trade done in August, about $75 million through our continuous equity offering program earlier in the year and then about $275 million through our internal programs. Those are our 401(k) and dividend reinvestment programs. We do not expect to issue any additional equity this year other than through our internal programs.
Slide 11 shows our estimated CapEx through 2019. And other than the change to 2015 that I previously covered, the ranges for 2016 through 2019 remain the same.
Slide 12 shows our estimates of authorized rate base through 2019 and these are consistent with the CapEx ranges on the previous slide. As a result, we estimate that 6% to 8% annual growth in our authorized rate base over this period. As Tony discussed, California's clean energy policies and our focus on system safety and reliability are driving significant investment in the coming years and support this strong growth profile.
I'll stop here so that we can now open the lines for your questions.

componenttextpreview: Jonathan, this is Kent. Let me kind of go through it by parts of the business, which really relate to the regulatory proceedings. So for the electric and gas distribution and generation, which is our General Rate Case, the high end reflects the amounts th
componenttext: Jonathan, this is Kent. Let me kind of go through it by parts of the business, which really relate to the regulatory proceedings. So for the electric and gas distribution and generation, which is our General Rate Case, the high end reflects the amounts that we requested in the 2017 General Rate Case. For gas transmission, the high end in 2017 reflects the amount that we requested in the gas transmission rate case. And then in 2018 and '19, we've just kept that amount flat with the 2017 request. And then for electric transmission, which is our TO case, we really only requested an amount through 2016, our TO17 case. And so our 2017 through 2019 levels are flat at the 2016 request. For the low end, basically, it's consistent with the low end that we've had out there already for 2016 for -- across the board.

componenttext: Can I just ask about the El Niño, concerns about the storms and the preparations there. How do you guys address cost recovery at the end of some just proportionally [ph] high storm costs this year versus next year? And how would that affect the numbers we think about ongoing earnings estimates?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Kent. We do have balancing account treatment in our current General Rate Case for major storms. In addition, for things like the wildfires we just had where in cases where the governor declares a disaster area, we also have the ability to seek rec
componenttext: This is Kent. We do have balancing account treatment in our current General Rate Case for major storms. In addition, for things like the wildfires we just had where in cases where the governor declares a disaster area, we also have the ability to seek recovery through a catastrophic event memorandum account. So there's a few different mechanisms that are in place in California.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess the next question, Tony, with the electric vehicle charging station decision was kind of a deviation from what you guys seem to have in message from the governor as far as his priorities are concerned. A, how do you think this is going t
componenttext: Okay. And I guess the next question, Tony, with the electric vehicle charging station decision was kind of a deviation from what you guys seem to have in message from the governor as far as his priorities are concerned. A, how do you think this is going to work out from meeting the governor's rules on vehicles? But second, when you look at the DRP, is there a disconnect between the goals of the governor and what the commission's proven to be supportive that you guys invested in?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, we thought that our initial proposal was totally consistent with the governor's goals on electric vehicles. I think the commission felt it was overly aggressive and wants to phase it in. And in terms of our spending estimates, it takes a
componenttext: Well, obviously, we thought that our initial proposal was totally consistent with the governor's goals on electric vehicles. I think the commission felt it was overly aggressive and wants to phase it in. And in terms of our spending estimates, it takes a while to gear up. It really doesn't affect any of the numbers that Kent is talking about. We just want to get the program up and running, and we think that once we get it running, we'll show that it's very well received and is consistent with the electric vehicle strategy in California. So it was disappointing we didn't get the full green light, but we're going to continue to work to get still a fairly aggressive program out there.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess -- what it means as far as the pacing of DRP capital, is there going to be more of a test for each one of these new initiatives along the way rather than maybe a more wholesale buying [ph] of what you need to do to accomplish their state goals
componenttext: And I guess -- what it means as far as the pacing of DRP capital, is there going to be more of a test for each one of these new initiatives along the way rather than maybe a more wholesale buying [ph] of what you need to do to accomplish their state goals?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, as Kent just said a minute ago, that the DRP capital is spread among the various regulatory cases. So our General Rate Case has some of it in, and that's where it will be addressed and it's being addressed now. We submitted that case and it
componenttext: Yes, I think, as Kent just said a minute ago, that the DRP capital is spread among the various regulatory cases. So our General Rate Case has some of it in, and that's where it will be addressed and it's being addressed now. We submitted that case and it will go through the hearing process. So I don't expect a separate rate-making proceeding for DRP. DRP expenditures will just be rolled into various other proceedings.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess 1 last question, just with the Edison case where the manufacturing tax deductions are -- they're kind of sloughed in this reduction in rate base and next rate case to call back those earnings. How is that affecting you guys from immediately wh
componenttext: And I guess 1 last question, just with the Edison case where the manufacturing tax deductions are -- they're kind of sloughed in this reduction in rate base and next rate case to call back those earnings. How is that affecting you guys from immediately where do you think to recognizing those earnings, those benefits during this GRC process? And if there was a precedent that the commission was pulling those back, would you guys need to change how you're recognizing them in your numbers?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Dinyar Mistry, the controller. We've taken a look at the Edison PD, and we think that our situation is different from Edison's. We just filed our 2017 GRC. So prospectively, the commission will consider our request over there. But at this point in
componenttext: This is Dinyar Mistry, the controller. We've taken a look at the Edison PD, and we think that our situation is different from Edison's. We just filed our 2017 GRC. So prospectively, the commission will consider our request over there. But at this point in time, we don't anticipate changing our treatment.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's something that we look at every time I'm with my Board of Directors. We discuss that dividend policy. We've not tied it to any specific outcome at the commission. What we're focusing on is what is the right time to address that. I'm well awar
componenttext: Well, that's something that we look at every time I'm with my Board of Directors. We discuss that dividend policy. We've not tied it to any specific outcome at the commission. What we're focusing on is what is the right time to address that. I'm well aware our investors have been very patient on this. We're committed to getting our dividend in line with our peers, but it's got to be at the right time, and we continue to assess that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, and just 1 follow-up question on the repairs deduction issue. Can you just refresh how you guys treating it and how -- is there any simple way to explain why your situation is different than Edison's?
componenttext: Great, and just 1 follow-up question on the repairs deduction issue. Can you just refresh how you guys treating it and how -- is there any simple way to explain why your situation is different than Edison's?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Dinyar again. So the rate-making for repairs is that customer rates are reduced for taxes that aren't currently paid to the IRS. That's the fundamental principle of the flow-through rate-making. And to the extent that there's a forecast diffe
componenttext: Yes, this is Dinyar again. So the rate-making for repairs is that customer rates are reduced for taxes that aren't currently paid to the IRS. That's the fundamental principle of the flow-through rate-making. And to the extent that there's a forecast difference between what was in the rate case and what actually occurred, during that rate case period, up or down, that forecast difference affects the bottom line. I would say the primary difference between us and the Edison case is that in the Edison PD, it indicated that its previous GRC request was based on a different methodology for calculating the tax repairs than was actually applied during that period. But for us, we've applied the same methodology for our actual that we used to develop the forecast. So I think that's probably the key difference.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just curious, when you think about longer term, do you expect to be a company that winds up growing earnings kind of in piece with rate base growth? Is there anything kind of structural that can make it something different than that over time?
componenttext: Just curious, when you think about longer term, do you expect to be a company that winds up growing earnings kind of in piece with rate base growth? Is there anything kind of structural that can make it something different than that over time?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Kent. I think the levels of rate base growth and CapEx frankly that, that we are having right now, it do require some equity issuance. And so generally, you see earnings grow with rate base, but you have to net out whatever equity issuanc
componenttext: Michael, this is Kent. I think the levels of rate base growth and CapEx frankly that, that we are having right now, it do require some equity issuance. And so generally, you see earnings grow with rate base, but you have to net out whatever equity issuance you need to support that level of CapEx. At lower levels, you could see that, but we're at higher levels, and I do think that requires some level of equity issuance.

componenttext: This is Kent. I'll just say, generally, probably the primary metric we look at is payout ratio. We look at the industry and it's pretty nicely comped. So it's pretty easy to see where the industry is, and we're a bit below that. And so that's the primary issue we'll be addressing.

componenttext: Okay, understood. Secondly, on the cost of capital mechanism and proceedings that will come up next year, it seems like, mechanically, the numbers are shaping out where an extension, perhaps, may not be too difficult of a suggestion to different stakeholders. I guess what I'm wondering is, are you aware of any issues out there that may prevent some of the stakeholders from wanting to consider an extension of the current mechanism? Any issues that may need to be worked through that could prevent that and instead make a full-blown cost of capital proceeding to take place?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Kent. So as you alluded to the normal process would have a slightly cost of capital application next spring, and that would be for rates effective January 2017. And I think what you're alluding to, I think everybody knows that last year we
componenttext: Brian, this is Kent. So as you alluded to the normal process would have a slightly cost of capital application next spring, and that would be for rates effective January 2017. And I think what you're alluding to, I think everybody knows that last year we and the other parties all agreed to extend the existing cost of capital as well as trigger mechanism by 1 year. And so the question is will that happen again this year, and I just say we're open to exploring that again given that, as you said, forecast bond rates haven't changed all that much since the proceeding was originally litigated. But whether or not that occurs depends on the extent to which all the parties are able to reach agreement.

componenttext: Understood. And then lastly, there's been a lot of consolidation happening in the industry. componenttext: This is Kent again. No, I think nothing has really changed there. I think that's a reasonable assumption to make going forward. I think, I said several times, a lot of the steps we do that are -- that is below the line is really important to the longer-term success of the company and our financials. headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So going back to the long-term outlook for CapEx in that discussion, what's the impact from SB350? How long out and is that included in any kind of near-term CapEx or GRC, just your thoughts around that?
componenttext: So going back to the long-term outlook for CapEx in that discussion, what's the impact from SB350? How long out and is that included in any kind of near-term CapEx or GRC, just your thoughts around that?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, SB350 really -- one of the primary components of it is the RPS requirements in the state. And generally, we have already been on track to meet the 33% RPS. This would now take us now to 50% eventually. We do that primarily through long-term contract
componenttext: Well, SB350 really -- one of the primary components of it is the RPS requirements in the state. And generally, we have already been on track to meet the 33% RPS. This would now take us now to 50% eventually. We do that primarily through long-term contracting. So it doesn't have a direct implication for our own CapEx which are primarily our distribution and transmission businesses.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Although I will add one place we may see some opportunities is in additional transmission out there. We've been successful in the competitive transmission bidding process here in California in the last couple of years. We continue to intend to stay involv
componenttext: Although I will add one place we may see some opportunities is in additional transmission out there. We've been successful in the competitive transmission bidding process here in California in the last couple of years. We continue to intend to stay involved in that process. But all of that is outside any of the years that we've been showing on the slides because recall that the current 33% is a 2020 objective. And so the new SB350 requirements will start showing up in the 2020s and you would see transmission then in that time frame. So I think the only conclusion you can draw is given California's commitment to clean energy environment is going to require the utilities to have continued investment to upgrade the system.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, what's your appetite right now for  ex California, outside of California, unregulated type of investments? Obviously, the SolarCity moves you made here seemed to be a pullback on that front. What's your thoughts and appetites for th
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, what's your appetite right now for  ex California, outside of California, unregulated type of investments? Obviously, the SolarCity moves you made here seemed to be a pullback on that front. What's your thoughts and appetites for the -- that unregulated type of investment?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to look at those opportunities. I think I've said this before. The California affiliate rules make it very difficult to start from scratch because there's -- it's very hard to take your utility expertise. And without taking them away from the
componenttext: We continue to look at those opportunities. I think I've said this before. The California affiliate rules make it very difficult to start from scratch because there's -- it's very hard to take your utility expertise. And without taking them away from the utility and moving them to a totally separate company and again even talk to their colleagues back at the old [ph] business, it's hard to justify when we've got so many growth opportunities in the utility right now.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. This is Janet Loduca, and thank you for joining us for the Pacific Gas and Electric Corporation's Third Quarter Earnings Call. Before I turn it over to Tony Earley, I want to remind you that our discussion today will include forwar
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. This is Janet Loduca, and thank you for joining us for the Pacific Gas and Electric Corporation's Third Quarter Earnings Call. Before I turn it over to Tony Earley, I want to remind you that our discussion today will include forward-looking statements about our outlook for future financial results, which is based on assumptions, forecasts, expectations and information currently available to management. Some of the important factors that could affect the company's actual financial results are described on the second page of today's slide deck. We also encourage you to review the Form 10-Q that will be filed with the SEC later today and the discussion of risk factors that appears there and in the 2014 annual report. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Tony.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Janet, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Our key focus areas remain unchanged. California continues to lead the U.S. in driving clean energy policies, and PG&E will play a critical role in helping to achieve the state's goals.
componenttext:
Thank you, Janet, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Our key focus areas remain unchanged. California continues to lead the U.S. in driving clean energy policies, and PG&E will play a critical role in helping to achieve the state's goals. We also know that safety must be at the core of all of our decisions, and our commitment to that is unwavering.
We continue to make progress towards resolving outstanding regulatory and legal issues while strengthening our safety and compliance programs. We believe that executing our strategies in these focus areas will provide the foundation for both operational and financial success. So I want to touch on some of the key developments this quarter before I turn it over to Kent to discuss our financial results. Geisha Williams and Nick Stavropoulos are also with us today, and they'll be available to take any questions that you have. In terms of our focus on clean energy, PG&E has a long history of action on climate change, and we've been a vocal advocate for policies that will move it forward. In fact, I recently participated in a meeting with President Obama to talk about the actions PG&E is taking to help drive clean energy policy and greenhouse gas reductions. We supported Governor Brown's recent move to increase the renewable energy target to 50% by 2030, and we're confident that we can get there.
We've been investing in the electric grid to enable both utility scale renewable and the growing distributed resources such as rooftop solar, electric vehicles and energy storage. During the quarter, we filed our proposal to update the current net metering rates. Our proposal supports the continued growth of rooftop solar while beginning the transition to a sustainable rate structure that also supports the necessary grid investments.
Our 2017 General Rate Case includes detailed proposal for continued grid modernization to ensure that we have the visibility and flexibility we'll need to enable all of the new distributed resources. Our General Rate Case also supports our goal on delivering customer expectations by providing customers with safe, reliable and affordable service.
Using a risk-based approach, we propose safety related investments across the system including replacing aging infrastructure, taking targeted actions to reduce risk and improving our emergency response. And we balance the necessary investments with affordability. Average residential bills will increase less than 3% and will remain below the national average.
In terms of reliability, the most significant event this quarter were the fires in Northern California. As you know, California is in its fourth year of a severe drought, and we've been partnering throughout the year with CAL FIRE and other stakeholders to address the challenging fire season. Our efforts have included things like increased patrols and vegetation management, as well as enhanced emergency response coordination. At one point, the state was simultaneously fighting 3 major wildfires across 300,000 acres of our service territory. In addition to restoring power to impacted customers, our crews came up with creative ways to meet our communities' needs in a very challenging time. So for example, we leveraged the new explorable power technology from our electric trucks to provide an evacuation shelter with backup electricity when its generator failed. The response from our customers and other stakeholders has been positive, and we're really proud of how safely and quickly our crews were able to perform the work.
As we publicly reported, CAL FIRE is investigating whether one of our electric lines could potentially have been the source of the Butte fire. That investigation is still underway and could take quite a while to complete. So we don't have any updates on that at this time.
On the heels of the state's historic drought, we're now hearing forecast about an El Niño winter, which could bring significant rainfall and cause mudslides and floods. Our team has been preparing for this possibility through a wide array of actions including updating our meteorological models and performing drills that simulate potential flood scenarios.
Finally, in terms of resolving outstanding regulatory issues, we recently received a report from the Safety and Enforcement Division on the gas distribution recordkeeping investigation. While the report identified a number of potential past violations, which we'll be responding to in the next month, we were pleased to see that it also acknowledged the progress we've made to improve our records. Over the last 2 years, we've implemented a number of new procedures that have been informed by extensive benchmarking and industry best practices. As we've said from the beginning, we know we have more work to do to enhance our distribution records and practices, and we're absolutely committed to getting that right.
Geisha and Nick recently had a chance to share some of the actions we've taken to improve our safety culture at the California Public Utilities Commission's first ever safety en banc. This was an opportunity for all 5 commissioners, the presidents of California's investor-owned utilities and a number of interveners to talk about what each of the utilities is currently doing around safety and what changes the commission might make to better incorporate safety into its proceedings. Nick and Geisha talked about the changes made by our Board of Directors to focus on safety, the strong link between our executive compensation programs and safety performance, our use of third-party experts in benchmarking and the way we engage our frontline crews around safety. The commission also had the opportunity here from other utilities and to start thinking about how to create common metrics to track and measure progress. I can tell you that we thought it was a really positive step forward in the conversation, and we look forward to continuing the dialogue with all the parties.
So before I turn this over to Kent, I just want to take a moment to thank him for all that he's done for PG&E. As you know, after 33 years with the company, Kent has decided to retire next year. Kent has done a tremendous job managing PG&E's financial activities during challenges that were some of the most complex in our industry. He's also been a great source of leadership and inspiration across the company. We're working through the succession process right now, and I'm thankful that Kent has agreed to stay on to ensure a smooth transition.
So thank you, Kent. And with that, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone. I plan to first cover our results for the quarter, and then I'll go through our updated guidance. Let me say upfront that the complexity of our rate case timing issues has made it especially difficult for you to forec
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone. I plan to first cover our results for the quarter, and then I'll go through our updated guidance. Let me say upfront that the complexity of our rate case timing issues has made it especially difficult for you to forecast quarterly results. However, we do expect solid results for the full year, and you'll see that when I get to guidance.
So I'll start with our quarterly results, which is on Slide 5. Earnings from operations were $0.84 in the third quarter and GAAP earnings, including our items impacting comparability, were $0.63. Our pipeline-related expenses in the quarter were $32 million pretax or $19 million after-tax shown in the table. This includes our cost to remediate encroachments on our pipeline  rights-of-way and to complete the remaining expense work for our pipeline safety enhancement plan. Our legal and regulatory-related expenses in the quarter were $14 million pretax or $8 million after-tax in the table, and here we have our costs for litigation and enforcement activities related to natural gas matters and regulatory communications.
Fines and penalties in the quarter were $142 million pretax as shown in the table below. This amount represents the disallowed capital work coming out of the final San Bruno penalty decision, which we're accruing as we do the work.
Finally, we received insurance recoveries in the quarter of $10 million pretax or $6 million after-tax, as shown in the table above. I'm pleased that we now resolved all San Bruno claims with our insurance carriers; and in total, we recovered $515 million through insurance.
Moving to Slide 6. You'll see our quarter-over-quarter comparison of earnings from operations of $1.73 in Q3 last year and $0.84 in Q3 this year, and this is where it gets a little complicated due to all the timing issues. In Q3 last year, we recorded 3 quarters’ worth of revenue increase associated with our 2014 General Rate Case. That's the biggest difference from Q3 of last year worth $0.47. $0.16 is associated with lower-cost recovery this year due to the timing of the gas transmission rate case. As you know, a lot of our transmission work is seasonal and the Q3 amount reflects a higher level of activity in the summer months. When we receive a final decision in the case next year, the revenue increase will be retroactive to January 1, 2015.
$0.09 relates to the timing of taxes, which reversed to 0 by year-end. $0.05 relates to regulatory and legal matters. This includes the impact of some favorable regulatory decisions in Q3 of last year as well as some legal costs incurred in Q3 of this year. Another $0.05 is associated with an increase in shares outstanding, and the impact here on share count is magnified by the fact that earnings in Q3 last year were so much higher as a result of booking 3 quarters’ worth of revenue increase to the GRC. $0.03 relates to the disposition of SolarCity stock in Q3 last year and $0.09 relates to a variety of smaller miscellaneous items, many of which are timing. And we've had positive miscellaneous items in previous quarters. These factors are partially offset by a $0.05 increase due to growth in rate base earnings. That's it for our Q3 results.
On Slide 7, you'll see our 2015 guidance. Previously, we've had a guidance range for earnings from operations of $2.90 to $3.10. Year-to-date, we've been trending towards the upper end of this range. Therefore, today, we're narrowing our range to between $3 and $3.10. There are a few other changes to this slide. We've reduced our range for pipeline-related expenses, and I'll say more about that in a moment. We've also updated our insurance recoveries just to reflect the amount we recovered in the quarter. Our resulting GAAP guidance is shown at the bottom of the table.
On Slide 8, we've updated our 2015 CapEx assumptions from $5.5 billion previously to $5.3 billion. There are really 2 main reasons for this update. First, our response to the recent wildfires displaced some of our planned work in electric operations. And second, we're realizing some efficiencies in gas operations, primarily related to our distribution pipe replacement program. The other assumptions for 2015 on this slide remain consistent with what we've previously provided.
Slide 9 reflects the updated range for pipeline-related expenses that I mentioned earlier. You can see we've decreased the upper end of that range from $150 million to $125 million. The lower end remains at $100 million. You'll recall that this item is primarily associated with our rights-of-way work, and we continue to expect that the cost of the overall program will not exceed $500 million.
Moving on to Slide 10. Our total equity needs for 2015 remain the same at $700 million to $800 million. Through the end of Q3, we've issued roughly $700 million of equity. This includes about $350 million through a block trade done in August, about $75 million through our continuous equity offering program earlier in the year and then about $275 million through our internal programs. Those are our 401(k) and dividend reinvestment programs. We do not expect to issue any additional equity this year other than through our internal programs.
Slide 11 shows our estimated CapEx through 2019. And other than the change to 2015 that I previously covered, the ranges for 2016 through 2019 remain the same.
Slide 12 shows our estimates of authorized rate base through 2019 and these are consistent with the CapEx ranges on the previous slide. As a result, we estimate that 6% to 8% annual growth in our authorized rate base over this period. As Tony discussed, California's clean energy policies and our focus on system safety and reliability are driving significant investment in the coming years and support this strong growth profile.
I'll stop here so that we can now open the lines for your questions.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] First question comes from the line of Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.
