headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Question just on the CapEx and I guess on the rate base ranges. Could you just talk to what is in the -- that kind of the base in the bottom end of the range? Is that just authorized spending and then the other things that you mentioned, what defines the
componenttext: Question just on the CapEx and I guess on the rate base ranges. Could you just talk to what is in the -- that kind of the base in the bottom end of the range? Is that just authorized spending and then the other things that you mentioned, what defines the shaded sections? Or is that in some other way, kind of being a little more clear about what exactly is in and out of the 2 pieces, 2 different levels?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, this is Kent. Let me kind of go through it by parts of the business, which really relate to the regulatory proceedings. So for the electric and gas distribution and generation, which is our General Rate Case, the high end reflects the amounts th
componenttext: Jonathan, this is Kent. Let me kind of go through it by parts of the business, which really relate to the regulatory proceedings. So for the electric and gas distribution and generation, which is our General Rate Case, the high end reflects the amounts that we requested in the 2017 General Rate Case. For gas transmission, the high end in 2017 reflects the amount that we requested in the gas transmission rate case. And then in 2018 and '19, we've just kept that amount flat with the 2017 request. And then for electric transmission, which is our TO case, we've really only requested an amount through 2016, our TO17 case. And so our 2017 through 2019 levels are flat at the 2016 request. For the low end, basically, it's consistent with the low end that we've had out there already for 2016 for -- across the board.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and how about the distribution resource plan, for example? Where does that fit into this, the range? Is that in the high end or no?
componenttext: Okay, and how about the distribution resource plan, for example? Where does that fit into this, the range? Is that in the high end or no?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We did not have a specific ask in that proceeding, but a lot of those types of investments for automating the system and so forth are included in our General Rate Case. So those components are included in the overall ask and, therefore, in the overall ran
componenttext: We did not have a specific ask in that proceeding, but a lot of those types of investments for automating the system and so forth are included in our General Rate Case. So those components are included in the overall ask and, therefore, in the overall range, the upper end of the range.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So put simply, if you've got everything you've asked for -- in place of the big outstanding cases you would come in at the high end.
componenttext: Okay. So put simply, if you've got everything you've asked for -- in place of the big outstanding cases you would come in at the high end.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct, and then, of course, we'll have updates because at some point we'll file another gas transmission case for beyond '17, and we'll also file additional transmission owner cases for beyond '16.
componenttext: That's correct, and then, of course, we'll have updates because at some point we'll file another gas transmission case for beyond '17, and we'll also file additional transmission owner cases for beyond '16.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Dan Eggers with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Dan Eggers with Crédit Suisse.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can I just ask about, with the El Niño, concerns about the storms and the preparations there. How do you guys address cost recovery at the end of what's disproportionally high storm costs this year against next year? And how would that affect the numbers
componenttext: Can I just ask about, with the El Niño, concerns about the storms and the preparations there. How do you guys address cost recovery at the end of what's disproportionally high storm costs this year against next year? And how would that affect the numbers we think about ongoing on earnings estimates?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Kent. We do have the balancing account treatment in our current General Rate Case for major storms. In addition, for things like the wildfires we just had where in cases where the governor declares a disaster area, we also have the ability to seek
componenttext: This is Kent. We do have the balancing account treatment in our current General Rate Case for major storms. In addition, for things like the wildfires we just had where in cases where the governor declares a disaster area, we also have the ability to seek recovery through a catastrophic event memorandum account. So there's a few different mechanisms that are in place in California.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess the next question, Tony, with the electric vehicle charging station decision was kind of a deviation from what you guys seemed to have in message from the governor as far as his priorities are concerned. A, how do you think this is going
componenttext: Okay. And I guess the next question, Tony, with the electric vehicle charging station decision was kind of a deviation from what you guys seemed to have in message from the governor as far as his priorities are concerned. A, how do you think this is going to work out from meeting the governor's rules on vehicles? But second, when you look at the DRP, is there a disconnect between the goals of the governor and what the commission's proven to be supportive that you guys invested in?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, we thought that our initial proposal was totally consistent with the governor's goals on electric vehicles. I think the commission felt it was overly aggressive and wants to phase it in. And in terms of our spending estimates, it takes a
componenttext: Well, obviously, we thought that our initial proposal was totally consistent with the governor's goals on electric vehicles. I think the commission felt it was overly aggressive and wants to phase it in. And in terms of our spending estimates, it takes a while to gear up. It really doesn't affect any of the numbers that Kent is talking about. We just want to get the program up and running, and we think that once we get it running, we'll show that it's very well received and is consistent with the electric vehicle strategy in California. So it was disappointing we didn't get the full green light, but we're going to continue to work to get still a fairly aggressive program out there.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess, what it means as far as the pacing of DRP capital, is there going to be more of a test for each one of these new initiatives along the way rather than maybe a more wholesale buy-in of what you need to do to accomplish the bigger state goals?
componenttext: And I guess, what it means as far as the pacing of DRP capital, is there going to be more of a test for each one of these new initiatives along the way rather than maybe a more wholesale buy-in of what you need to do to accomplish the bigger state goals?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, as Kent just said a minute ago, that the DRP capital is spread among the various regulatory cases. So our General Rate Case has some of it in, and that's where it will be addressed and it's being addressed now. We submitted that case and it
componenttext: Yes, I think, as Kent just said a minute ago, that the DRP capital is spread among the various regulatory cases. So our General Rate Case has some of it in, and that's where it will be addressed and it's being addressed now. We submitted that case and it will go through the hearing process. So I don't expect a separate rate-making proceeding for DRP. DRP expenditures will just be rolled into various other proceedings.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess one last question, just with the Edison case where the manufacturing tax deductions are -- they're kind of sloughed in this reduction in rate base and next rate case to call back those earnings. How is that affecting you guys from the way you'
componenttext: And I guess one last question, just with the Edison case where the manufacturing tax deductions are -- they're kind of sloughed in this reduction in rate base and next rate case to call back those earnings. How is that affecting you guys from the way you're thinking about recognizing those earnings, those benefits during this GRC process? And if there was a precedent that the commission was pulling those back, would you guys need to change how you're recognizing them in your numbers?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Dinyar Mistry, the controller. We've taken a look at the Edison PD, and we think that our situation is different from Edison's. We just filed our 2017 GRC. So prospectively, the commission will consider our request over there. But at this point in
componenttext: This is Dinyar Mistry, the controller. We've taken a look at the Edison PD, and we think that our situation is different from Edison's. We just filed our 2017 GRC. So prospectively, the commission will consider our request over there. But at this point in time, we don't anticipate changing our treatment.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Fleishman with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Fleishman with Wolfe Research.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first of all, Kent, I guess an early goodbye, we'll miss you. Secondly, on the similar question regarding the Edison PD under GRC. Is there any policy issues there that concern you at all, relative to your case?
componenttext: So first of all, Kent, I guess an early goodbye, we'll miss you. Secondly, on the similar question regarding the Edison PD under GRC. Is there any policy issues there that concern you at all, relative to your case?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The major issue we've seen has been the repairs issue, which Dinyar just addressed, and we do think we're in a little bit different situation. That's the biggest one that we've been watching.
componenttext: The major issue we've seen has been the repairs issue, which Dinyar just addressed, and we do think we're in a little bit different situation. That's the biggest one that we've been watching.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, and then the -- maybe just on the criminal case. I know there's been a lot of activity. Can you maybe just give us an update on whether any of the allegations have been thrown out at this point? And do we still have some kind of, I guess, trial in
componenttext: Great, and then the -- maybe just on the criminal case. I know there's been a lot of activity. Can you maybe just give us an update on whether any of the allegations have been thrown out at this point? And do we still have some kind of, I guess, trial in March of next year?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Tony. Let me start off and then I'll let Hyun jump in. Those of you who have been involved in major litigation -- this is just the pretrial motion stage. There's a lot of activity going on. There'll continue to be more activity leading up to
componenttext: Yes, this is Tony. Let me start off and then I'll let Hyun jump in. Those of you who have been involved in major litigation -- this is just the pretrial motion stage. There's a lot of activity going on. There'll continue to be more activity leading up to the trial. The trial is still scheduled for next spring. We'll see what happens as we get closer to it, but Hyun, why don't you comment on where we are?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Steve, we did file a number of motions and all the motions have been submitted to the judge. So we're just waiting for the judge to issue his ruling on our motions.
componenttext: So Steve, we did file a number of motions and all the motions have been submitted to the judge. So we're just waiting for the judge to issue his ruling on our motions.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then on the GT&S case, I know there's a lot of arguments, I guess, today, but just in terms of -- is there any relevant update there in terms of potential outcomes that we should be aware of?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then on the GT&S case, I know there's a lot of arguments, I guess, today, but just in terms of -- is there any relevant update there in terms of potential outcomes that we should be aware of?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Steve Malnight from reg affairs. Really, we don't have any additional updates. Timing still looks like next year for the case, and we look forward to the oral argument later today.
componenttext: This is Steve Malnight from reg affairs. Really, we don't have any additional updates. Timing still looks like next year for the case, and we look forward to the oral argument later today.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Weinstein with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Weinstein with UBS.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: When do you guys think you'll be in a position to discuss 2016 guidance and dividend policy?
componenttext: When do you guys think you'll be in a position to discuss 2016 guidance and dividend policy?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's something that we look at every time I'm with my Board of Directors. We discuss that dividend policy. We've not tied it to any specific outcome at the commission. What we're focusing on is what is the right time to address that. I'm well awar
componenttext: Well, that's something that we look at every time I'm with my Board of Directors. We discuss that dividend policy. We've not tied it to any specific outcome at the commission. What we're focusing on is what is the right time to address that. I'm well aware that our investors have been very patient on this. We're committed to getting our dividend in line with our peers, but it's got to be at the right time, and we continue to assess that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of timing of guidance, I'd just say we're looking towards hopefully getting back in a regular rhythm with guidance, and I'd like to think we'll be in a position to do that in the first quarter.
componenttext: In terms of timing of guidance, I'd just say we're looking towards hopefully getting back in a regular rhythm with guidance, and I'd like to think we'll be in a position to do that in the first quarter.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, and just one follow-up question on the repairs deduction issue. Can you just refresh how are you guys treating it and how -- is there any simple way to explain why your situation is different than Edison's?
componenttext: Great, and just one follow-up question on the repairs deduction issue. Can you just refresh how are you guys treating it and how -- is there any simple way to explain why your situation is different than Edison's?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Dinyar again. So the rate-making for repairs is that customer rates are reduced for taxes that aren't currently paid to the IRS. That's the fundamental principle of the flow-through rate-making. And to the extent that there's a forecast diffe
componenttext: Yes, this is Dinyar again. So the rate-making for repairs is that customer rates are reduced for taxes that aren't currently paid to the IRS. That's the fundamental principle of the flow-through rate-making. And to the extent that there's a forecast difference between what was in the rate case and what actually occurred, during that rate case period, up or down, that forecast difference affects the bottom line. I would say the primary difference between us and the Edison case is that in the Edison PD, it indicated that its previous GRC request was based on a different methodology for calculating the tax repairs than was actually applied during that period. But for us, we've applied the same methodology for our actuals that we used to develop the forecast. So I think that's probably the key difference.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Lapides with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Lapides with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just curious, when you think about longer term, do you expect to be a company that winds up growing earnings kind of in pace with rate base growth? Is there anything kind of structural that can make it something different than that over time?
componenttext: Just curious, when you think about longer term, do you expect to be a company that winds up growing earnings kind of in pace with rate base growth? Is there anything kind of structural that can make it something different than that over time?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Kent. I think the levels of rate base growth and CapEx frankly that we are having right now, it do require some equity issuance. And so generally, you see earnings grow with rate base, but you have to net out whatever equity issuance you
componenttext: Michael, this is Kent. I think the levels of rate base growth and CapEx frankly that we are having right now, it do require some equity issuance. And so generally, you see earnings grow with rate base, but you have to net out whatever equity issuance you need to support that level of CapEx. At lower levels, you could see that, but we're at higher levels, and I do think that requires some level of equity issuance.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And second, Tony, you made the comment about you talk to the board about dividend and dividend policy. Can you dive a little bit into that -- when you think about dividend policy, are we talking a payout ratio, a growth rate, a dividend yiel
componenttext: Got it, okay. And second, Tony, you made the comment about you talk to the board about dividend and dividend policy. Can you dive a little bit into that -- when you think about dividend policy, are we talking a payout ratio, a growth rate, a dividend yield kind of target relative to the peer group? I'm just trying to think about what are the metrics you and the board are looking at when you all have the discussions about dividend policy?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Kent. I'll just say, generally, probably the primary metric we look at is payout ratio. We look at the industry and it's pretty nicely clumped. So it's pretty easy to see where the industry is, and we're a bit below that. And so that's the primary
componenttext: This is Kent. I'll just say, generally, probably the primary metric we look at is payout ratio. We look at the industry and it's pretty nicely clumped. So it's pretty easy to see where the industry is, and we're a bit below that. And so that's the primary issue we'll be addressing.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Hugh Wynne with Alliance Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Hugh Wynne with Alliance Bernstein.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, I was just wondering if you might bring us up-to-date on any developments that could shed light on potential outcomes of the gas distribution records OII and then similarly with the M&A developments with respect to the CAL FIRE investi
componenttext: Two questions. One, I was just wondering if you might bring us up-to-date on any developments that could shed light on potential outcomes of the gas distribution records OII and then similarly with the M&A developments with respect to the CAL FIRE investigation into the origins of the Butte bush fire?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me comment on CAL FIRE. Their investigation is ongoing. We're cooperating with. We don't have any updates. Traditionally, those investigations take quite some time because it's hard because all the evidence is burned up. So it takes a lot of work to f
componenttext: Let me comment on CAL FIRE. Their investigation is ongoing. We're cooperating with. We don't have any updates. Traditionally, those investigations take quite some time because it's hard because all the evidence is burned up. So it takes a lot of work to figure out exactly what happened. With respect to the proceedings, Steve, you -- I don't think we have any updates there.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we don't really have any updates on the OII. We saw the SED filing as was mentioned earlier. We'll file our rebuttal testimony in November and then we would expect hearings on that in January, first part of the year.
componenttext: No, we don't really have any updates on the OII. We saw the SED filing as was mentioned earlier. We'll file our rebuttal testimony in November and then we would expect hearings on that in January, first part of the year.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Chin of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Chin of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Question on dividend, just going back to that. Given some of the changes that will take place in the C suite over the next 12 months, does that, to some degree, make you think that you ought to maintain flexibility on the dividend until the next set of C
componenttext: Question on dividend, just going back to that. Given some of the changes that will take place in the C suite over the next 12 months, does that, to some degree, make you think that you ought to maintain flexibility on the dividend until the next set of C suite executives comes in? Or does that not factor in your thinking about how you think about the timing of the dividend policy going forward?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think it has any connection at all with the dividend policy. Dividend policy is based upon our financial situation and our assessment of what's going on in the regulatory front and it doesn't have anything to do with the C suite changes.
componenttext: I don't think it has any connection at all with the dividend policy. Dividend policy is based upon our financial situation and our assessment of what's going on in the regulatory front and it doesn't have anything to do with the C suite changes.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. Secondly, on the cost of capital mechanism and proceedings that will come up next year, it seems like, mechanically, the numbers are shaping out where an extension, perhaps, may not be too difficult of a suggestion to different stakehold
componenttext: Okay, understood. Secondly, on the cost of capital mechanism and proceedings that will come up next year, it seems like, mechanically, the numbers are shaping out where an extension, perhaps, may not be too difficult of a suggestion to different stakeholders. I guess what I'm wondering is, are you aware of any issues out there that may prevent some of the stakeholders from wanting to consider an extension of the current mechanism? Any issues that may need to be worked through that could prevent that and instead make a full-blown cost of capital proceeding to take place?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Kent. So as you alluded to, the normal process would have us file a cost of capital application next spring, and that would be for rates effective January 2017. And I think what you're alluding to, I think everybody knows that last year we
componenttext: Brian, this is Kent. So as you alluded to, the normal process would have us file a cost of capital application next spring, and that would be for rates effective January 2017. And I think what you're alluding to, I think everybody knows that last year we and the other parties all agreed to extend the existing cost of capital as well as trigger mechanism by 1 year. And so the question is will that happen again this year, and I just say we're open to exploring that again given that, as you said, forecast bond rates haven't changed all that much since the proceeding was originally litigated. But whether or not that occurs depends on the extent to which all the parties are able to reach agreement.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, at this point, you're not aware of any specific issues that may cause 1 or 2 stakeholders to say, "We really ought to revisit this despite the mathematics looking very similar versus last year."
componenttext: So I guess, at this point, you're not aware of any specific issues that may cause 1 or 2 stakeholders to say, "We really ought to revisit this despite the mathematics looking very similar versus last year."

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, if I were, I wouldn't be talking about it with investors.
componenttext: Brian, if I were, I wouldn't be talking about it with investors.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then lastly, there's been a lot of consolidation happening in the industry. If, Tony, you could give just your quick thoughts on consolidation, how you think about it in the industry here. A lot of your peers have been using their balance
componenttext: Understood. And then lastly, there's been a lot of consolidation happening in the industry. If, Tony, you could give just your quick thoughts on consolidation, how you think about it in the industry here. A lot of your peers have been using their balance sheets, and I think it's safe to say that the California utilities are in a much better balance sheet position than others. But just kind of your up -- latest on thought -- latest thoughts there?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Generally, we don't comment on specifics on M&A opportunities. I will say, one interesting observation though, is everyone is buying a gas company. We've already got 4.5 million gas customers. I think we're in pretty good shape.
componenttext: Generally, we don't comment on specifics on M&A opportunities. I will say, one interesting observation though, is everyone is buying a gas company. We've already got 4.5 million gas customers. I think we're in pretty good shape.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gregg Orrill with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gregg Orrill with Barclays.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that as you get out of '17 and '18, your forecast for rate base on -- forecast includes flat assumptions for the gas and electric transmission. Is there maybe -- since you are going to update it at some point, is there a better modeling assu
componenttext: You mentioned that as you get out of '17 and '18, your forecast for rate base on -- forecast includes flat assumptions for the gas and electric transmission. Is there maybe -- since you are going to update it at some point, is there a better modeling assumption that we might use or would those updates maybe get you to the higher end of rate base growth that you're thinking about?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Kent. We just done that because it's a fairly mechanical way to do it, and we don't want to call future cases that we've not yet filed. So but you can apply judgment to it. You can look at our historic track record, what we've done over the last f
componenttext: This is Kent. We just done that because it's a fairly mechanical way to do it, and we don't want to call future cases that we've not yet filed. So but you can apply judgment to it. You can look at our historic track record, what we've done over the last few years, adjust that, whatever you think is appropriate. We just try to keep it simple and objective when we present it to you, all for your consideration.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have a follow-up question from the line of Mike Lapides.
componenttext: We have a follow-up question from the line of Mike Lapides.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Real quick, on the rate base charter exhibit Slide 12, that still excludes the incremental quip that actually generate some earnings. I think that's a number of around $1 billion, $1.7 billion, $1.8 billion, somewhere in that range. And you've kind of com
componenttext: Real quick, on the rate base charter exhibit Slide 12, that still excludes the incremental quip that actually generate some earnings. I think that's a number of around $1 billion, $1.7 billion, $1.8 billion, somewhere in that range. And you've kind of commented historically that, that earnings from quip, while not in rate base, would largely be offset by kind of corporate costs that aren't recoverable in rates. Do you still kind of see that trend? Or is there the potential to manage some of those corporate costs down over time?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Kent again. No, I think nothing has really changed there. I think that's a reasonable assumption to make going forward. I think, I've said several times, a lot of the steps we do that are -- that is below the line is really important to the longer
componenttext: This is Kent again. No, I think nothing has really changed there. I think that's a reasonable assumption to make going forward. I think, I've said several times, a lot of the steps we do that are -- that is below the line is really important to the longer-term success of the company and our financials. It includes our advertising, a lot of our charitable contributions, just bread and butter for a utility. And we're going to continue to make those necessary investments.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Travis Miller with Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Travis Miller with Morningstar.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So going back to the long-term outlook for CapEx in that discussion, what's the impact from SB350? How long out and is that included in any kind of near-term CapEx or GRC? Just your thoughts around that.
componenttext: So going back to the long-term outlook for CapEx in that discussion, what's the impact from SB350? How long out and is that included in any kind of near-term CapEx or GRC? Just your thoughts around that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, SB350 really -- one of the primary components of it is the RPS requirements in the state. And generally, we have already been on track to meet the 33% RPS. This would now take us now to 50% eventually. We do that primarily through long-term contract
componenttext: Well, SB350 really -- one of the primary components of it is the RPS requirements in the state. And generally, we have already been on track to meet the 33% RPS. This would now take us now to 50% eventually. We do that primarily through long-term contracting. So it doesn't have a direct implication for our own CapEx, which are primarily our distribution and transmission businesses.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Although I will add one place we may see some opportunities is in additional transmission out there. We've been successful in the competitive transmission bidding process here in California in the last couple of years. We continue to intend to stay involv
componenttext: Although I will add one place we may see some opportunities is in additional transmission out there. We've been successful in the competitive transmission bidding process here in California in the last couple of years. We continue to intend to stay involved in that process. But all of that is outside any of the years that we've been showing on the slides because recall that the current 33% is a 2020 objective. And so the new SB350 requirements will start showing up in the 2020s and you would see transmission then in that time frame. So I think the only conclusion you can draw is given California's commitment to clean energy environment, it's going to require the utilities to have continued investment to upgrade the system.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, what's your appetite right now for ex California, outside of California, or unregulated type of investments? Obviously, the SolarCity moves you made here seemed to be a pullback on that front. What's your thoughts and appetites for
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, what's your appetite right now for ex California, outside of California, or unregulated type of investments? Obviously, the SolarCity moves you made here seemed to be a pullback on that front. What's your thoughts and appetites for the -- that unregulated type of investment?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to look at those opportunities. I think I've said this before. The California affiliate rules make it very difficult to start from scratch because there's -- it's very hard to take your utility expertise. And without taking them away from the
componenttext: We continue to look at those opportunities. I think I've said this before. The California affiliate rules make it very difficult to start from scratch because there's -- it's very hard to take your utility expertise. And without taking them away from the utility and moving them to a totally separate company and they can't even talk to their colleagues back at the old business, it's hard to justify it when we've got so many growth opportunities in the utility right now.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: There are currently no additional questions waiting from the phone lines.
componenttext: There are currently no additional questions waiting from the phone lines.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, this is Janet again. I want to thank everyone for joining us, and we hope you have a safe day. Thank you.
componenttext: All right, this is Janet again. I want to thank everyone for joining us, and we hope you have a safe day. Thank you.
